EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES
Helix Water District has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training; consideration to safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Chlorination System; an aggressive preventive maintenance program; and comprehensive operating procedures.  Helix Water DistrictA?s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of all chemicals including regulated substances.
 
STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
Chlorine is injected into the water in order to disinfect it and to prevent bacterial growth while the water travels through pipelines. The maximum intended inventory for this facility is approximately 48,000 pounds of chlorine kept in 24 one-ton containers.  

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary:
Scenario Description: Per the EPA Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for the Chlorination System.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary:
Scenario Description: Per the EPA Regulations, one alternative-case release scenario has been defined for the Chlorination System.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  

Risk Considerations:
Although the storage and use of chlorine has inherent potential risks and the release scenarios can potentially reach sensitive populations within the community, the Helix Water District has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the facility and plant personnel to make the worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion an

alysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a chlorine release.  The facility has a scrubber, rupture discs, and chlorine gas detection.  For protection of employees and responders, safety showers and respiratory equipment are available on site.

RISK MANAGEMENT PREVENTION PROGRAM
As part of the implementation of the RMP Program 3, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Helix Water District to manage process safety issues associated with the use of chlorine. Prevention Program 3 elements include:

A?68.65    Process Safety Information (PSI) 
A?68.67    Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
A?68.69     Operating Procedures (OP)
A?68.71    Training (TRN)
A?68.73    Mechanical Integrity (MI)
A?68.75    Management of Change (MOC)
A?68.77    Pre-Startup Review (PSSR)
A?68.79    Compliance Audits (CA)
A?68.81    Incident Investigation (II)
A?68.83    Employee Participation (EP)
A?68.85    Hot Work Permit (HWP)
A?68.87    Contractors (CO)
A?68.90    Emergency Planning & Response (EP&R)

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no RMP-applicable releases of chlorine at the facility in at least the past five (5) years.  

FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE
The use of flammable materials at the Helix Water District facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 

FLAMMABLES: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE
The use of flammable materials at the Helix Water District facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
Helix Water District has implemented an Emergency Response Program (ERP) to prepare for potential incidents, respond to them effectively, and recover from their impacts.  The ERP has includ

ed a set of potential incidents that are used for emergency drills, including accidental release of toxic gases.  The facility has HAZWOPER trained responders who are able to react to emergency situations.  Emergency training is provided annually to the emergency response team. The ERP meets Cal/OSHA 8 CCR 5192 and Cal/OSHA 8 CCR 3220.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Helix Water District is extremely diligent in the handling of chlorine.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the PHA Report.  The recommendations listed in the report have been closed.  Recommendations generated in the 2007 PHA Revalidation have also been completed.
